header.title: BBC in sexism row over cartoon hippo in Hey Duggee who wants to be a fireman
header.subtitle: THE BBC was accused of sexism yesterday after a children’s TV show used the word “fireman” instead of “firefighter”.
header.postText: Hey Duggee cartoon character Roly the hippo said he wanted to dress up as a fireman.', 'That prompted a furious backlash from London Fire Brigade, who said the “preferred, respectful, inclusive, non-gendered” term of firefighter should be used.', 'Tory MP David Davies told the Daily Express: “This is obviously ludicrous political correctness.', '“Of course women do a fantastic job fighting fires and saving lives.', '“But it is ridiculous jumping up and down because of a character on a children’s TV show saying he wants to be a fireman not a firefi ghter.', 'If it was a male character,then obviously he will want to be a fireman.', 'The London Fire Brigade’s first female commissioner Dany Cotton has told how she wants to  shake off outdated language.', 'She said: The first woman firefighter joined London Fire Brigade in 1982 and it’ s ridiculous that 36 years later people are still surprised to see women firefighters or calling them firemen.', 'During the episode of Hey Duggee, cartoon characters dressed up as different professionals.', 'Roly the hippo announced he was going to dress up as a fireman.', 'But a London Fire Brigade firefighter tweeted: Isn’ t it sad when one of our longest - serving firefighters, a woman who fought the King’ s Cross fire 30 years ago, still has to watch TV with her two year - old grandson and explain why the character in Hey Duggee is referred to as a fireman', 'This term is VERY outdated and the term firefighter is the preferred, respectful, inclusive, non - gendered term that should be widely used by all media but especially the BBC.', 'Women have been firefighting for over 40 years now...Non - sexist, all - inclusive terminology is important if we want to encourage girls, as well as boys, to be future firefighters.', 'The BBC said: Animated characters are shown dressing up in costumes depicting roles such as a plumber, pirate, knight and farmer but these roles are occupied by girl characters as well as boys and infers these roles are all gender neutral.CBeebies strives to avoid stereotyping.
